Ivana: "It's rare to see a man at this table," she purrs, her eyes flickering with mischief. "You must be new here... or are you interested in more than the drink?" Ivana grins coyly as Hans approaches, her cleavage nearly spilling out of her revealing dress.
Hans: "N-no!" he stammers, so surprised he nearly drops his papers. "I'm actually here to ask about your last mission, Miss Ivana." Regaining his composure and summoning his courage, Hans takes a few steps forward. "I've got a few questions. First of all, what is a suggested method for avoiding blame after an act of sabotage?"
Ivana: "Well~" She coquishly tilts her head to the side and daintily puts a finger to her lipstick-colored lips in mock-thought, "You can try to commit acts for which many people could be responsible, such as damaging a military car or truck on the street. So basically..." Ivana flashes a wry grin, "...don't get caught red-handed! If you get my meaning, hehe~" She says, as she plays with a strand of her hair.
Hans: _I can't believe my ears. Did she just say what I think she just said_? After a few seconds' thought, Hans decides it's best to pretend he didn't hear anything. "I, uh, see..." he manages to say. "Now, moving on, I really want to know more about sabotage. How can you avoid blame for an act of sabotage, according to the text?"
Ivana: "Aww, you're no fun, Hans, you know that? Reminds me of my colleagues..." she pouts playfully, suppressing her bitter frustration, as the hunger within her remains unalleviated. "But whatever. Look here..." Ivana stands from her table and walks over to a wall, illustrating her points as she speaks, "The answer is that you should try to commit acts many people could have done, like blowing out wiring in a factory at a central fire box. Understand?" She puts down her chalk and leans suggestively against a nearby wall, "Now, Hans... do you think we could 'intercept' each other later...?"
Hans: "I-I'm good, thank you, Miss Ivana," Hans manages to sputter out, barely withstanding the alluring assault. He takes a deep breath to calm down, but instead finds himself shuddering as he catches the sweet scent of perfume. However, he presses on asking questions, for the sake of his mission, "Actually, there was a bit more I wanted to know. What is a suggested tool for sabotage?"
Ivana: "Ghh... you know, Hans, you're breaking a poor woman's heart," Ivana pouts, half-serious this time, as she picks her chalk up again. "But when it comes to tools, the thing you've gotta know is that a knife or nail can be carried normally on your person and used as a multi-purpose instrument. Isn't it wonderful to learn new things?" Putting down her chalk then mustering the most innocent puppy eyes imaginable. "Do you think we could... celebrate this acquisition of knowledge together?"
Hans: "I should really..." He tries to say he declines, but as he gazes into Ivana's beautiful eyes, he's drawn in by their surprising innocence and warmth. Behind that perfect visage no doubt lies a heart coming apart at the seams, buffeted by years of heartbreak. "Oh, bother." Hans mumbles. "We... can meet at a cafe, if that'd be alright..." he continues, wondering what kind of mess he's getting myself into. Just then, a shock of remembering strikes him, "Oh! But I have one more question, sorry about the mood, but I should really get this answered: What is a suggested method for avoiding blame after an act of sabotage?"
Ivana: "I... I..." For the first time in the conversation Ivana stumbles over her words, her soul on fire with vindication, the joy of acceptance, pure glee. She can do nothing but stand there, smiling at Hans for what feels like an eternity, until she finally regains her composure. "T-to answer your question," she begins, her voice shaky, "You can try to commit acts for which many people could be responsible, such as damaging a military car or truck on the street. Now..." Ivana shyly walks over to Hans and lightly, sweetly kisses him on the cheek, "Office hours are over. Please no more questions. I'll see you at that cafe."

What is a suggested method for avoiding blame after an act of sabotage?
You can try to commit acts for which many people could be responsible, such as damaging a military car or truck on the street.

(bIt should not be difficult to prepare leaflets and other media for the saboteur about the choice of weapons, time, and targets which will insure the saboteur against detection and retaliation. Among such suggestions might be the following: (1) Use materials which appear to be innocent. A knife or a nail file can be carried normally on your person; either is a multi-purpose instrument for creating damage. Matches, pebbles, hair, salt, nails, and dozens of other destructive agents can be carried or kept in your living quarters without exciting any suspicion whatever. If you are a worker in a particular trade or industry you can easily carry and keep such things as wrenches, hammers, emery paper, and the like. (2) Try to commit acts for which large numbers of people could be responsible. For instance, if you blow out the wiring in a factory at a central fire box, almost anyone could have done it. On-the-street sabotage after dark, such as you might be able to carry out against a military car or truck, is another example of an act for which it would be impossible to blame you. (3) Do not be afraid to commit acts for which you might be blamed directly, so long as you do so rarely, and as long as you have a plausible excuse: you dropped your wrench across an electric circuit because an air raid had kept you up the night before and you were half-dozing at work. Always be profuse in your apologies.
Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
